'''Across Language Server''' is a software platform for [[Computer-assisted translation|computer-assisted translation (CAT)]] that includes additional features for the management of projects. The software is produced and sold by [[Across Systems|Across Systems GmbH]], a company located and founded in [[Karlsbad (Baden)|Karlsbad]] in 2005 as a [[Corporate spin-off]] of [[Nero AG]] and which maintains an additional site in [[Glendale, California]].
The functional principle is similar to the one [[SDL Trados]], XTM and [[memoQ]] feature: Just like the server solutions of these two programs, Across Language Server also saves translation units or terminology entries (depending on the project's configuration) into a local or a central MSSQL database.
Besides the "Server", which is available in different versions, there is also a single-user version called ''Across Translator Edition'', working with a local MS-SQL database. This single-user application is able to connect to the server, enabling to work on both local and Across-Server-based projects. Freelance translators can acquire the ''Basic Edition'' of the single-user version for free.
== History == Version 5 of the MS-SQL-database-based Across Language Server was launched in 2009.<ref>[http://multilingual.texterity.com/multilingual/20091011?pg=16#pg16 Review of Across Language Servers by Richard Sikes] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029191745/http://multilingual.texterity.com/multilingual/20091011?pg=16#pg16 |date=October 29, 2013 }}</ref> Version 6 of Across Language Server was released on 2 July 2014.<ref>http://www.across.net/unternehmen/news-pressemeldungen/ansicht/die-welt-spricht-v6-neueste-version-des-across-language-server-ab-sofort-verfuegbar/</ref> Version 6.3 was introduced on 26 November 2015.<ref>https://www.across.net/en/news/across-language-server-v63-new-collaboration-options/</ref>

{{Infobox person | name = Anil Acharya | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = Indian | other_names = | known_for = Editor of ''Anustup'' literary magazine | occupation = Essayist, writer, poet }}
'''Anil Acharya''' is an Indian [[Bengali people|Bengali]] essayist, short story writer and poet. In 1966, he founded the [[Bengali language|Bengali]] literary quarterly and [[Little magazine movement|little magazine]] ''Anustup''.<ref name=CalcuttaYellowPages>[http://www.calcuttayellowpages.com/adver/108702editors-profile.html Anustup website's profile of the editor. Retrieved on 9 September 2013]</ref>
==Education== Acharya graduated with an honors degree in English literature from the [[Scottish Church College]].<ref>''Some Alumni of Scottish Church College'' in ''175th Year Commemoration Volume''. Scottish Church College, April 2008, p. 588.</ref> Thereafter he earned his master's degree in English literature from the University of Calcutta. He started publishing the literary quarterly ''Anustup'' as an undergraduate student at Scottish Church College in 1966.<ref name=CalcuttaYellowPages/>
==Career== Since his college days, he has written poems, short stories and essays in Bengali and English. After earning a postgraduate degree in English literature, he started out as a lecturer, and later became a reader and then associate professor in English at the [[Serampore College]], within the aegis of the [[University of Calcutta]].<ref name=CalcuttaYellowPages/> He was also Head of the Department of English and set up the Communicative English programme in Serampore College.
He is a member of the Publisher and Bookseller's Guild, the organisers of the Kolkata Book Fair, which is Asia's largest book fair and the most attended book fair in the world. He was elected Secretary of the Guild for three successive terms, between 1996-1998, and during his tenure, the noted French Philosopher Jacques Derrida inaugurated the Kolkata Book Fair in 1997.
He has spent a life in writing and editing his quarterly journal, and has also founded an English language literary periodical for translated short stories from Bengali, called ''Harvest''.<ref name=CalcuttaYellowPages/> In 1970, he assisted the Australian director [[Paul Cox (director)|Paul Cox]] as the assistant director in making the documentary on Calcutta. He was also the associate producer of Paul Cox's film "Force of Destiny" released in 2014. He is currently associated with St. Thomas' College of Engineering and Technology, Kolkata.<ref name=PaulCox>[http://www.paulcox.com.au/site/item.cfm?item=5FFF5055C29F442E670EB862A4A55DE9 Calcutta]{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
Between February 2013 and February 2015, he wrote a regular Sunday column in the Bengali newspaper 'Ei Somoy', called "Nipaatone Siddho". It documented the myriad experiences, that played out across four decades in the Bengali cultural and political landscape, and shaped Anustup and what it stands for. He is also the author of the Bengali book titled "Parasmaipadi" which is a collection of his selected articles.
==About ''Anustup''== ''Anustup'' is a literary journal.<ref>''No Revolutionary but Editor of a Revolutionary Paper'' in ''Samar Sen''. Nityapriya Ghosh, Sahitya Akademi, 2001, p. 77.</ref> In 1972, it was the first to have an independent publishing wing. True to the vision of "Little Magazine" movement that emerged in the 70's in Bengal, its aim is to publish works that established publishers would overlook. The editorial board wanted to promote promising authors and new genres of writing. Due to the initial efforts of this journal, many others followed suit and this led to a qualitative improvement in terms of production in contemporary Bengali literature.<ref name=littlemag>[http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2012-07-01/kolkata/32494033_1_special-edition-publishing-tagore/2 The New Golden Age Retrieved 8 October 2013]</ref> Since its inception, ''Anustup'' has seen the likes of contributions from [[Amiya Bagchi]], [[Partha Chatterjee (scholar)|Partha Chatterjee]], [[Ashis Nandy]], [[Shankha Ghosh]], Gautam Bhadra, [[Hemanga Biswas]] and [[Ranajit Guha]].<ref name=Flashback>[http://www.telegraphindia.com/1080720/jsp/calcutta/story_9559837.jsp Little things mean a lot] Retrieved 8 October 2013.</ref>
==Recognition== In recognition of his efforts, in 2012, he was appointed as a ''Tagore National Scholar'' by the [[Ministry of Culture (India)|Ministry of Culture]] of the [[Government of India]].<ref name=NL>[http://www.nationallibrary.gov.in/nat_lib_stat/pdfs/NewsLetter%20Jan_Jun%202012.pdf National Library Kolkata newsletter]</ref>
==See also== *[[Little magazine movement]] *[[Kolkata Little Magazine Library And Research Center]]

{{for|the other Samsung virtual assistant|S Voice}} {{Infobox software | title = Bixby | name = Bixby | logo = Samsung Bixby Logo.svg | screenshot = Samsung Bixby screenshot.png | screenshot size = 250px | caption = Bixby information screen on the [[Samsung Galaxy Note 8]] | collapsible = yes | author = [[Samsung Electronics|Samsung]] | developer = [[Samsung]] | released = {{start date and age|2017|4|21}} | ver layout = stacked | operating system = [[Android (operating system)|Android]] | language = [[English language|English (US only)]], [[Korean language|Korean]], [[Chinese language|Chinese (China)]] | genre = [[Intelligent personal assistant]] | website = {{url|http://bixby.samsung.com}} }} '''Bixby''' is a [[Virtual assistant (artificial intelligence)|virtual assistant]] developed by [[Samsung Electronics]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Bixby|url=http://www.samsung.com/global/galaxy/apps/bixby/|website=Samsung|accessdate=7 November 2017}}</ref>
On March 20, 2017, Samsung announced the voice-powered digital assistant named "Bixby".<ref>{{cite web|title = Bixby : A New Way to Interact with Your Phone|url=https://news.samsung.com/global/bixby-a-new-way-to-interact-with-your-phone|website=SAMSUNG Newsroom|access-date=5 April 2017}}</ref> Bixby was introduced alongside the [[Samsung Galaxy S8|Samsung Galaxy S8 and S8+]], as well as the [[Samsung Galaxy Tab series|Samsung Galaxy Tab A]] during the Samsung Galaxy Unpacked 2017 event, which was held on March 29, 2017.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Pham|first1=Sherisse|title=Samsung's new AI assistant will take on Siri and Alexa|url=http://money.cnn.com/2017/03/21/technology/samsung-bixby-ai-s8-note-7-apple-google/index.html|accessdate=30 March 2017|work=[[CNNMoney]]|date=21 March 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Baig|first1=Edward|title=Samsung promises its Galaxy S8 Bixby assistant will be 'fundamentally different'|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/columnist/baig/2017/03/20/samsung-promises-its-galaxy-s8-bixby-assistant-viv-labs/99409962/|accessdate=30 March 2017|work=[[USA Today]]|date=20 March 2017|language=en}}</ref> [[Samsung]] officially unveiled Bixby a week before launch but it only made its first appearance during the event.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://venturebeat.com/2017/03/29/everything-samsung-announced-at-its-2017-unpacked-launch-event/|title=Everything Samsung announced at its Unpacked 2017 launch event|date=2017-03-29|website=VentureBeat|access-date=2017-03-30}}</ref> Bixby can also be [[Sideloading|sideloaded]] on older Galaxy devices running Android Nougat.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Schoon|first1=Ben|title=Here’s how to install Bixby and the Galaxy S8’s new launcher on other Samsung devices|url=https://9to5google.com/2017/04/03/how-to-install-bixby-on-galaxy-s7/|website=9to5Google|accessdate=4 April 2017|date=3 April 2017}}</ref>
Bixby represents a major reboot for [[S Voice]], Samsung's voice assistant app introduced in 2012 with the [[Samsung Galaxy S III|Galaxy S III]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.androidauthority.com/samsung-galaxy-s8-bixby-digital-assistant-s-voice-748940/|title=Galaxy S8's Bixby assistant to be based on S-Voice, not Viv Labs tech|publisher=Android Authority|author=Scott Adam Gordon|date=10 February 2017|access-date=5 April 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theverge.com/circuitbreaker/2017/2/10/14573954/samsung-ai-assistant-bixby-viv-s-voice|title=So, what is Samsung's Bixby AI assistant really made of?|work=[[The Verge]]|first=James|last=Vincent|date=10 February 2017|access-date=5 April 2017}}</ref>
In May 2017, Samsung announced that Bixby would be coming to its line of Family Hub 2.0 refrigerators, making it the first non-mobile product to include the virtual assistant.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theverge.com/circuitbreaker/2017/5/15/15640542/samsung-bixby-assistant-smart-hub-2-0|title=Samsung’s Bixby assistant is coming to smart fridges|last=Carman|first=Ashley|date=15 May 2017|work=[[The Verge]]|access-date=20 May 2017}}</ref>
In October 2017, Samsung announced the release of Bixby 2.0 during its annual developer conference in San Francisco. The new version is set to be rolled out across the company’s line of connected products, including smartphones, TVs, and refrigerators. Moreover, third parties will be allowed to develop applications for Bixby using the Samsung Developer Kit.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://techcrunch.com/2017/10/18/bixby-2-0-takes-center-stage-at-samsungs-developer-conference/|title=Bixby 2.0 takes center stage at Samsung’s Developer Conference|last=Heater|first=Brian|work=TechCrunch|access-date=2017-11-07|language=en}}</ref>
==Features== Bixby comes with three parts, known as ''Bixby Voice'', ''Bixby Vision'' and ''Bixby Home''.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnet.com/news/samsung-bixby-assistant-galaxy-s8-hands-on/|title=Samsung Galaxy S8's Bixby assistant needs to grow up fast|last=Dolcourt|first=Jessica|date=2017-03-29|work=[[CNET]]|access-date=2017-03-30|language=en}}</ref>
===Bixby Voice=== With ''Bixby Voice'', the user can trigger Bixby by calling it or doing a long press of the Bixby Button located below the volume rocker. A while before the phone's release, the Bixby Button was reprogrammable and could be set to open other applications or assistants, such as [[Google Assistant]]. Near the phone's release, however, this ability was removed with a firmware update, but can be remapped using third party apps.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.androidcentral.com/samsung-bixby|title=What is Bixby and is it like Google Assistant?|last=Karner|first=Jen|date=2017-03-29|work=Android Central|access-date=2017-03-30}}</ref>
===Bixby Vision=== ''Bixby Vision'' is built into the camera app and can "see" what one can see as it is essentially an augmented reality camera that can identify objects in real time, search for them on various services, and offer the user to purchase them if available. Bixby is also able to translate text, read QR codes, and recognize landmarks.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.theverge.com/2017/3/29/15097744/samsung-bixby-galaxy-s8-assistant-vs-siri-alexa-android|title=Three things we know Samsung’s new assistant can do on the Galaxy S8|last=Bohn|first=Dieter|date=2017-03-29|work=The Verge|access-date=2018-08-30}}</ref>
===Bixby Home=== ''Bixby Home'' can be found by swiping to the right on the home screen or doing a short press on the Bixby Button. It is a vertically scrolling list of information that Bixby can interact with, for example, weather, fitness activity, and buttons for controlling their smart home gadgets.<ref name=":0" />
Bixby supports three languages including Chinese. It also supports contextual search and visual search.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.ttgadget.com/bixby-samsung-voice-virtual-assistant/|title=Bixby : Samsung Virtual Assistant [ Full Guide ]|date=2017-03-23|work=TTGADGET - Tips and Tutorials for Gadget|access-date=2017-04-05|language=en-US|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170827130854/http://www.ttgadget.com/bixby-samsung-voice-virtual-assistant/|archive-date=2017-08-27|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
==Language and country availability== [[Samsung Electronics|Samsung]] reported that Bixby would not be operational on the [[United States|US]] version of the [[Samsung Galaxy S8|Samsung Galaxy S8 and S8+]] when the devices were first shipped to consumers on April 21, 2017. [[Samsung Electronics|Samsung]] stated that the key features of Bixby, including Vision, Home and Reminder, would be available with the global launch of the smartphones. Bixby Voice was intended to be made available in the [[United States|US]] on the [[Samsung Galaxy S8|Galaxy S8 and S8+]] later that spring.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnet.com/news/samsung-bixby-voice-assistant-wont-ship-with-galaxy-s8/|title=Samsung Galaxy S8 hits launch snag with Bixby voice assistant|date=2017-04-11|work=CNET|access-date=2018-08-30|language=en}}</ref> However, the release of the English version was postponed as Samsung had problems getting Bixby to fully understand the language.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.androidpolice.com/2017/05/31/wsj-samsungs-english-language-bixby-rollout-delayed-english-hard/|title=WSJ: Samsung's English-language Bixby rollout delayed because English is hard|last=Whitwam|first=Ryan|date=2017-05-31|work=Android Police|access-date=2018-08-30|language=en-US}}</ref>
As of April 2018, Bixby is available in over 195 countries, but only in Korean, English (US only), and Chinese (Mandarin). The Chinese version of Bixby is only available on devices officially sold in Mainland China.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2017/08/22/samsung-bixby-expands-to-over-200-countries-in-battle-with-alexa-siri.html|title=Samsung Bixby expands to over 200 countries in battle with Amazon Alexa, Apple Siri|last=Kharpal|first=Arjun|date=22 August 2017|work=[[CNBC]]|access-date=27 August 2017}}</ref> Bixby Korean was launched on May 1, 2017 (KST).<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.zdnet.com/article/samsung-launches-galaxy-s8-bixby-voice-command-in-korea/|title=Samsung launches Galaxy S8 Bixby voice command in Korea|last=Mu-Hyun|first=Cho|date=2017-05-01|work=ZDNet|access-date=2018-08-30|language=en}}</ref>
==Compatible devices== === Flagship smartphones and tablets === ==== Galaxy S ==== *[[Samsung Galaxy S9]] (including S9+) *[[Samsung Galaxy S8]] (including S8+) *[[Samsung Galaxy S8 Active]] *[[Samsung Galaxy S7]] (including S7 Edge with Bixby Home and Reminder Only Through APK; S Voice used instead) *[[Samsung Galaxy S6]] (including S6 Edge with Bixby Home and Reminder Only Through APK; S Voice used instead)

=== Mid-range smartphones and tablets === ==== Galaxy A ==== *[[Samsung Galaxy A8 (2018)]] (including A8+; Bixby Home, Reminder and Vision only) *[[Samsung Galaxy A8 Star (2018)]] *[[Samsung Galaxy A7 (2018)]] *[[Samsung Galaxy A9 (2018)]] *[[Samsung Galaxy A6/A6+]] (Bixby Home and Vision) *[[Samsung Galaxy A7 (2017)]] (available to users in South Korea only; Bixby Home and Reminder only)<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.androidauthority.com/samsung-galaxy-a7-2017-bixby-launches-786837/|title=The Galaxy A7 (2017) features Bixby in South Korea|last=Rutnik|first=Mitja|date=2017-07-12|work=Android Authority|access-date=2018-08-30|language=en-US}}</ref> *[[Samsung Galaxy Tab A 8.0|Samsung Galaxy Tab A 8.0 (2017)]] (Bixby Home and Reminder only)<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.gsmarena.com/user_manual_confirms_bixby_for_samsung_galaxy_tab_a_80_2017-news-26921.php|title=User manual confirms Bixby for Samsung Galaxy Tab A 8.0 (2017)|work=GSMArena.com|access-date=2018-08-30|language=en-US}}</ref>

{{Merge from|Emerdata|discuss=Talk:Emerdata#Merge |date=May 2018}} {{EngvarB|date=March 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2018}} {{Infobox company | name = Cambridge Analytica Ltd | logo = Cambridge_Analytica_logo.png | logo_size = 125px | type = Subsidiary | location = London, England | foundation = 2013 | defunct = 1 May 2018 | successor = [[Emerdata]] | key_people = [[Alexander Nix]] (CEO){{cite web |url=https://news.sky.com/story/behind-the-scenes-at-donald-trumps-uk-digital-war-room-10626155 |title=Behind the scenes at Donald Trump's UK digital war room |last1=Cheshire |first1=Tom |date=21 October 2016 |publisher=[[Sky News]]}}
[[Robert Mercer (businessman)|Robert Mercer]] (investor){{cite news|last1=Cadwalladr |first1=Carole |title='I made Steve Bannon's psychological warfare tool': meet the data war whistleblower |url=https://www.theguardian.com/news/2018/mar/17/data-war-whistleblower-christopher-wylie-faceook-nix-bannon-trump |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |accessdate=18 March 2018 |date=18 March 2018 |df=dmy-all}}
[[Rebekah Mercer]] (investor)
[[Steve Bannon]] (vice president, former){{cite web |last=Illing |first=Sean |title=Cambridge Analytica, the shady data firm that might be a key Trump-Russia link, explained |website=Vox |date=16 October 2017 |url=https://www.vox.com/policy-and-politics/2017/10/16/15657512/cambridge-analytica-christopher-wylie-facebook-trump-russia | access-date=24 March 2018}} | parent = [[SCL Group]]{{cite web |title=Cambridge Analytica LLC: Private Company Information |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=434877108 |website=[[Bloomberg News|Bloomberg]] |accessdate=20 March 2018}} | website = {{URL|cambridgeanalytica.org}} }} '''Cambridge Analytica Ltd''' ('''CA''') was a British [[political consulting]] firm which combined [[data mining]], [[data broker]]age, and [[data analysis]] with [[strategic communication]] during the electoral processes.{{cite web |last=Editorial |first=Reuters |title=Factbox: Who is Cambridge Analytica and what did it do? |website=U.S. |date=20 March 2018 |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-facebook-cambridge-analytica-factbox/factbox-who-is-cambridge-analytica-and-what-did-it-do-idUSKBN1GW07F | access-date=23 March 2018}}{{cite web |title=Exposed: Undercover secrets of Trump's data firm |website=Channel 4 News |date=20 March 2018 |url=https://www.channel4.com/news/exposed-undercover-secrets-of-donald-trump-data-firm-cambridge-analytica | access-date=22 March 2018}} It was started in 2013 as an offshoot of the [[SCL Group]]. The company closed operations in 2018, although related firms continued in existence. The company was partly owned by the family of [[Robert Mercer (businessman)|Robert Mercer]], an American [[hedge-fund]] manager who supports many politically conservative causes.{{cite news |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/politics/features/2015-11-12/is-the-republican-party-s-killer-data-app-for-real- |first=Sasha |last=Issenberg |authorlink=Sasha Issenberg |title=Cruz-Connected Data Miner Aims to Get Inside U.S. Voters' Heads |publisher=Bloomberg |date=12 November 2015 |accessdate=2 February 2016 |df=dmy-all}} The firm maintained offices in London, New York City, and Washington, DC. CEO [[Alexander Nix]] has said CA was involved in 44 US political races in 2014. In 2015, it performed data analysis services for [[Ted Cruz's presidential campaign]]. In 2016, CA worked for [[Donald Trump presidential campaign, 2016|Donald Trump's presidential campaign]]{{cite journal |date=10 October 2016 |title=Silent Partners |journal=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |page=44 |author=Alex Altman}} as well as for [[Leave.EU]] (one of the organisations campaigning in the United Kingdom's [[United Kingdom European Union membership referendum, 2016|referendum on European Union membership]]). CA's role in those campaigns has been controversial and is the subject of ongoing criminal investigations in both countries.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/06/us/politics/cambridge-analytica.html|title=Data Firm Says 'Secret Sauce' Aided Trump; Many Scoff|last=Confessore|first=Nicholas|date=6 March 2017|work=The New York Times|access-date=7 March 2017|last2=Hakim|first2=Danny|issn=0362-4331}}{{cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/netzwelt/netzpolitik/donald-trump-und-die-daten-ingenieure-endlich-eine-erklaerung-mit-der-alles-sinn-ergibt-a-1124439.html|title=Ich ganz allein habe Trump ins Amt gebracht|last2=Schnack|first2=Thies|date=6 December 2016|work=[[Der Spiegel]]|last1=Reinbold|first1=Fabian}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2017/mar/04/cambridge-analytics-data-brexit-trump |title=Watchdog to launch inquiry into misuse of data in politics |last=Doward |first=Jamie |date=4 March 2017 |work=[[The Guardian]]|access-date=14 June 2017 |last2=Cadwalladr |first2=Carole |issn=0261-3077 |last3=Gibbs |first3=Alice |df=dmy-all}} Political scientists question CA's claims about the effectiveness of its methods of targeting voters.{{Cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/monkey-cage/wp/2018/03/23/four-and-a-half-reasons-not-to-worry-that-cambridge-analytica-skewed-the-2016-election/ |title=Four and a half reasons not to worry that Cambridge Analytica skewed the 2016 election|last=Trump|first=Kris-Stella|date=23 March 2018|work=Washington Post|access-date=23 March 2018|issn=0190-8286}} In March 2018, multiple media outlets broke news of Cambridge Analytica's business practices. ''[[The New York Times]]'' and ''[[The Observer]]'' reported that the company had [[Facebook–Cambridge Analytica data breach|acquired and used personal data about Facebook users]] from an external researcher who had told Facebook he was collecting it for academic purposes. Shortly afterwards, [[Channel 4 News]] aired undercover investigative videos showing Nix boasting about using prostitutes, bribery [[sting operation]]s, and [[honey trapping|honey traps]] to discredit politicians on whom it conducted [[opposition research]], and saying that the company "ran all of (Donald Trump's) digital campaign". In response to the media reports, the [[Information Commissioner's Office|Information Commissioner of the UK]] pursued a [[warrant (law)|warrant]] to search the company's servers.{{cite web |url=http://www.theweek.co.uk/92390/cambridge-analytica-ceo-admits-to-dirty-tricks |title=Cambridge Analytica CEO 'admits to dirty tricks' |work=The Week}}{{cite web |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-03-20/cambridge-analytica-used-disappearing-emails-in-campaign-report |title=Cambridge Analytica Boasted of Disappearing Emails in Campaigns |date=20 March 2018 |publisher=Bloomberg L.P.}} Facebook banned Cambridge Analytica from advertising on its platform, saying that it had been deceived.{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/03/17/us/politics/cambridge-analytica-trump-campaign.html |title=How Trump Consultants Exploited the Facebook Data of Millions |last=Rosenberg |first=Matthew |date=17 March 2018 |work=The New York Times|access-date=17 March 2018 |last2=Confessore |first2=Nicholas |issn=0362-4331 |last3=Cadwalladr |first3=Carole |df=dmy-all}}{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/news/2018/mar/17/cambridge-analytica-facebook-influence-us-election |title=Revealed: 50 million Facebook profiles harvested for Cambridge Analytica in major data breach |date=17 March 2018 |accessdate=18 March 2018 |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |first1=Carole |last1=Cadwalladr |first2=Emma |last2=Graham-Harrison |df=dmy-all}} On 23 March 2018, the [[High Court of Justice|British High Court]] granted the Information Commissioner's Office a warrant to search Cambridge Analytica's London offices.{{Cite news |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2018/03/23/uk-high-court-grants-cambridge-analytica-search-warrant-to-ico.html |title=UK High Court grants Cambridge Analytica search warrant to ICO |last=CNBC |date=23 March 2018 |work=CNBC|access-date=23 March 2018}} The personal data of approximately 87 million{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/04/04/technology/mark-zuckerberg-testify-congress.html |title="Facebook Says Cambridge Analytica Harvested Data of Up to 87 Million Users" in ''The New York Times'' |publisher=Nytimes.com |date= |accessdate=2018-06-05}} Facebook users were acquired via the 270,000 Facebook users who used a Facebook app called "This Is Your Digital Life."{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2018/apr/10/facebook-notify-users-data-harvested-cambridge-analytica|title=How to check whether Facebook shared your data with Cambridge Analytica|first=Alex|last=Hern|date=10 April 2018|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=3 July 2018}} By giving this third-party app permission to acquire their data, back in 2015, this also gave the app access to information on the user's friends network; this resulted in the data of about 87 million users, the majority of whom had not explicitly given Cambridge Analytica permission to access their data, being collected. The app developer breached Facebook's terms of service by giving the data to Cambridge Analytica.{{Cite news |url=https://www.recode.net/2018/3/17/17134072/facebook-cambridge-analytica-trump-explained-user-data |title=Here's how Facebook allowed Cambridge Analytica to get data for 50 million users |work=Recode|access-date=27 March 2018}} On 1 May 2018, Cambridge Analytica and its parent company filed for [[insolvency|insolvency proceedings]] and closed operations.{{Cite news |url=https://www.engadget.com/2018/05/02/cambridge-analytica-is-shutting-down-following-facebook-scandal/ |title=Cambridge Analytica is shutting down following Facebook scandal |last=Lumb |first=David |date=2 May 2018 |work=[[Engadget]] |access-date=2 May 2018}}{{cite web |title=Cambridge Analytica and Scl Elections Commence Insolvency Proceedings and Release Results of Independent Investigation into Recent Allegations |url=https://ca-commercial.com/news/cambridge-analytica-and-scl-elections-commence-insolvency-proceedings-and-release-results-3 |website=CA Commercial |publisher=Cambridge Analytica |accessdate=2 May 2018 |language=en |date=2 May 2018}} Alexander Taylor, a former director for Cambridge Analytica, was appointed director of [[Emerdata]] on 28 March 2018.{{cite news|last1=Nichols|first1=Shaun|title=Cambridge Analytica dismantled for good? Nope: It just changed its name to Emerdata|url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2018/05/02/cambridge_analytica_shutdown/|accessdate=2 May 2018|publisher=The Register|date=2 May 2018|language=en}} ==History== Cambridge Analytica (SCL USA) was incorporated in January 2015 with its registered office in Westferry Circus, London and just one staff member, its director and CEO Alexander James Ashburner Nix (also appointed in January 2015).{{cite web |title=Filing record for Cambridge Analytica (UK) Limited – Company number 09375920 |url=https://beta.companieshouse.gov.uk/company/09375920 |website=beta.companieshouse.gov.uk |publisher=Companies house, UK |accessdate=23 March 2018}} Nix is also the director of nine similar companies sharing the same registered offices in London, including Firecrest technologies, [[Emerdata]] and six SCL Group companies including "SCL elections limited".{{cite web |title=Alexander James Ashburner NIX – Appoinments |url=https://beta.companieshouse.gov.uk/officers/YEplkqBMfc6Rp3dbPs57pN3aqO4/appointments |website=beta.companieshouse.gov.uk |publisher=Companies house, UK Government |accessdate=23 March 2018}} [[Nigel Oakes]] founded [[SCL Group]], which is the parent company of Cambridge Analytica.{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/asia/old-etonian-smoothie-fails-to-buff-indonesian-leaders-image-711373.html |title=Old Etonian smoothie fails to buff Indonesian leader's image |author= |date=6 August 2000 |website=independent.co.uk |accessdate=21 March 2018}} [[File:Web Summit 2017 - Centre Stage Day 3 SAM 7454 (24415941378).jpg|thumb|left|Cambridge Analytica CEO [[Alexander Nix]] speaking in November 2017.]] Publicly, SCL Group called itself a "global election management agency",{{cite web |url=http://scl.cc/ |title=SCL Group – Home |website=scl.cc |df=dmy-all}} ''Politico'' reported it was known for involvement "in [[military deception|military disinformation]] campaigns to social media branding and [[voter]] targeting".{{cite news |url=http://www.politico.com/story/2015/07/ted-cruz-donor-for-data-119813 |first=Kenneth |last=Vogel |authorlink=Kenneth Vogel |title=Cruz partners with donor's 'psychographic' firm |publisher=[[Politico]] |date=7 July 2015 |accessdate=27 December 2015 |df=dmy-all}} SCL's involvement in the political world has been primarily in the developing world where it has been used by the military and politicians to study and manipulate public opinion and political will. ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]'' writer Sharon Weinberger compared one of SCL's hypothetical test scenarios to fomenting a coup. Cambridge Analytica was founded by conservative businessmen [[Steve Bannon]] and Robert Mercer. A minimum of 15 million dollars has been invested into the company by Mercer, according to ''The New York Times''.{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/03/19/us/cambridge-analytica-alexander-nix.html |first=Matthew |last=Rosenberg |title=Cambridge Analytica, Trump-Tied Political Firm, Offered to Entrap Politicians |date=19 March 2018 |accessdate=19 March 2018 |df=dmy-all}} Bannon's stake in the company was estimated at 1 to 5 million dollars, but he divested his holdings in April 2017 as required by his role as [[White House Chief Strategist]].{{cite web |url=http://www.mcclatchydc.com/news/politics-government/white-house/article200917134.html |first1=Ben |last1=Wieder |first2=Anita |last2=Kumar |title=Bannon sold Cambridge Analytica stake, fined for late ethics report |work=[[McClatchy]] |date=20 February 2018 |accessdate=20 March 2018 |df=dmy-all}} In March 2018, [[Rebekah Mercer|Jennifer Mercer]] and [[Mercer Family Foundation|Rebekah Anne Mercer]] became directors of Emerdata limited.{{cite web |title=Appoinment as directors |date=16 March 2018 |url=https://beta.companieshouse.gov.uk/company/10911848/filing-history |publisher=Companies house |accessdate=23 March 2018}} In March 2018 it became public by [[Whistleblower]] [[Christopher Wylie]], that Cambridge Analytica's first activities where founded on a data set, which its parent company SCL bought 2014 from a company named Global Science Research founded by [[Aleksandr Kogan]]Hannes Grassegger und Mikael Krogerus, in: [[Tages-Anzeiger]]: [https://www.tagesanzeiger.ch/ausland/europa/Ich-habe-nur-gezeigt-dass-es-die-Bombe-gibt/story/17474918 «Ich habe nur gezeigt, dass es die Bombe gibt» (I only showed, that there is a bomb)] , 3. 20th 2018 who worked as an psychologist at Cambridge. Per the Associated Press, [[Data Propria]], a data analysis firm launched May 2018, is run by former officials at Cambridge Analytica.{{cite web |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/ap-trump-2020-working-with-ex-cambridge-analytica-staffers/2018/06/15/ebdde7e2-70c0-11e8-b4d8-eaf78d4c544c_story.html |title=AP: Trump 2020 working with ex-Cambridge Analytica staffers |author=Jeff Horwitz |date=15 June 2018 |work=Associated Press |via=WashingtonPost.com |access-date=18 June 2018}}{{cite web |url=https://www.scmagazine.com/data-propria-heir-to-cambridge-analytica-working-for-rnc-possibly-trump-campaign/article/774206/ |title=Data Propria, heir to Cambridge Analytica, working for RNC, possibly Trump campaign |author=Teri Robinson |date=18 June 2018 |website=scmagazine.com |access-date=18 June 2018}}{{cite web |url=https://www.accesswire.com/500425/CloudCommerce-Launches-Data-Propria-Inc-Its-New-Data-Analytics-Division |title=CloudCommerce Launches Data Propria, Inc., Its New Data Analytics Division |author= |date=May 29, 2018 |website=accesswire.com |access-date=18 June 2018}} In July 2018, several former Cambridge Analytica staff launched [[Auspex International]], a company intended to influence politics and society in Africa and the Middle East.https://www.wired.co.uk/article/wired-awake-130718https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-44807093https://www.theinquirer.net/inquirer/news/3035777/cambridge-analyticas-latest-wants-your-google-search-historyhttps://boingboing.net/2018/07/11/zombie-analytica.htmlhttps://www.ft.com/content/1c8a5e74-6901-11e8-8cf3-0c230fa67aechttps://www.ft.com/content/d92164fe-8514-11e8-96dd-fa565ec55929 ==Methods== CA's data analysis methods were to a large degree based on the academic work of Michal Kosinski. In 2008, Kosinski had joined the Psychometrics Centre of [[Cambridge University]] where he then developed with his colleagues a profiling system using general online data, Facebook-likes, and [[smartphone]] data.{{cite web |url=https://www.dasmagazin.ch/2016/12/03/ich-habe-nur-gezeigt-dass-es-die-bombe-gibt/ |author=Mikael Krogerus, Hannes Grassegger |title=Ich habe nur gezeigt, dass es die Bombe gibt |publisher=[[Das Magazin]] |language=German |date=3 December 2016 |accessdate=7 December 2016 |df=dmy-all}}{{cite journal |doi=10.1073/pnas.1218772110 |title=Private traits and attributes are predictable from digital records of human behavior |journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences |volume=110 |issue=15 |page=5802 |year=2013 |last1=Kosinski |first1=M |last2=Stillwell |first2=D |last3=Graepel |first3=T|pmc=3625324 }} He showed that with a limited number of "likes", people can be analysed better than friends or relatives can do and that individual psychological targeting is a powerful tool to influence people. CA would collect data on voters using sources such as [[demographics]], [[consumer behaviour]], [[Computer and network surveillance|internet activity]], and other public and private sources. According to ''[[The Guardian]]'', CA used psychological data derived from millions of Facebook users, largely without users' permission or knowledge.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2015/dec/11/senator-ted-cruz-president-campaign-facebook-user-data |author=Davies, H |title=Ted Cruz using firm that harvested data on millions of unwitting Facebook users |work=The Guardian |date=11 December 2015 |accessdate=7 February 2016 |df=dmy-all}} Another source of information was the "Cruz Crew" [[mobile app]] that tracked physical movements and contacts and according to the [[Associated Press]], invaded personal data more than previous presidential campaign apps.{{cite news |url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/2db0fc93cf664a63909e26e708e91c67/cruz-app-data-collection-helps-campaign-read-minds-voters |first1=Michael |last1=Biesecker |first2=Julie |last2=Bykowicz |title=Cruz app data collection helps campaign read minds of voters |agency=[[Associated Press]] |date=11 February 2016 |accessdate=13 February 2016 |df=dmy-all}} {{quote|text=Today in the United States we have somewhere close to four or five thousand data points on every individual ... So we model the personality of every adult across the United States, some 230 million people.|author=Alexander Nix, chief executive of Cambridge Analytica |source=October 2016.}} The company claimed to use "data enhancement and [[audience segmentation]] techniques" providing "[[psychographic]] analysis" for a "deeper knowledge of the target audience". The company uses the [[Big Five personality traits|Big Five model]] of personality Using what it calls "[[behavioral targeting|behavioral]] [[microtargeting]]" the company indicates that it can predict "[[needs]]" of subjects and how these needs may change over time. Services then can be individually targeted for the benefit of its clients from the political arena, governments, and companies providing "a better and more actionable view of their key audiences." According to [[Sasha Issenberg]], CA indicates that it can tell things about an individual he might not even know about himself.{{cite news |url=http://www.cbc.ca/passionateeye/episodes/the-persuasion-machine-of-silicon-valley |agency=Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and British Broadcasting Corporation |title=The Persuasion Machine of Silicon Valley |publisher=[[CBC News]] |date=17 February 2018 |accessdate=17 February 2018 |df=dmy-all}} CA derived much of its personality data on [[online survey]]s which it conducts on an ongoing basis. For each political client, the firm would narrow voter segments from 32 different [[personality style]]s it attributes to every adult in the United States. The personality data would inform the tone of the language used in ad messages or voter contact scripts, while additional data is used to determine voters' stances on particular issues.{{cite web |url=http://adage.com/article/campaign-trail/cruz-s-data-company-works-night-3m-payout/302515 |title=Cruz's Data Company Works into the Night After Big $3 Million Payout |website=[[Advertising Age]]| access-date = 26 February 2016 |df=dmy-all}} The data would get updated with monthly surveys, asking about political preferences and how people get the information they use to make decisions. It also covered consumer topics about different [[brand engagement|brands and preferred products]], building up an image of how someone shops as much as how they vote.{{cite web |url=http://dcinno.streetwise.co/2016/02/08/political-ad-targeting-cambridge-analytica-adtech |title=Inside the Tech That Puts Political Ads on Your Screen |website=DC Inno| access-date = 26 February 2016 |df=dmy-all}} ===''Channel 4 News'' investigation=== ''[[Channel 4 News]]'', a news programme broadcast by the [[Public service broadcasting in the United Kingdom|British public service]] [[Channel 4]], conducted a four-month investigation into Cambridge Analytica starting in November 2017. An undercover reporter posed as a potential customer for Cambridge Analytica, hoping to help Sri Lankan candidates get elected. Video footage from this operation was published on 19 March 2018.{{cite news |url=https://www.channel4.com/news/cambridge-analytica-revealed-trumps-election-consultants-filmed-saying-they-use-bribes-and-sex-workers-to-entrap-politicians-investigation |title=Revealed: Trump's election consultants filmed saying they use bribes and sex workers to entrap politicians |work=Channel 4 News |date=19 March 2018 |accessdate=20 March 2018 |df=dmy-all}} From the footage, Cambridge Analytica executives say they worked on over 200 elections across the world. Alexander Nix was recorded in this investigation, talking "unguardedly about the company's practices".{{cite news|last=Cadwalladr |first=Carole |authorlink1=Carole Cadwalladr |last2=Graham-Harrison |first2=Emma |title=The Cambridge Analytica Files : 'I made Steve Bannon's psychological warfare tool': meet the data war whistleblower |date=17 March 2018 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/news/2018/mar/17/data-war-whistleblower-christopher-wylie-faceook-nix-bannon-trump |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |accessdate=19 March 2018 |df=dmy-all}} Nix said that his company uses honey traps, bribery stings, and prostitutes, for opposition research.{{cite web |url=http://www.theweek.co.uk/92390/cambridge-analytica-ceo-admits-to-dirty-tricks |title=Cambridge Analytica CEO 'admits to dirty tricks' |work=The Week |date=20 March 2018 |accessdate=20 March 2018 |df=dmy-all}} For example, Nix offered to discredit political opponents in Sri Lanka with suggestive videos using "beautiful Ukrainian girls" and offers of bribes, even if the opponents did not accept the offers.{{cite web |url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/british-firm-sends-girls-to-entrap-politicians-wpthxqhwv |title=Cambridge Analytica sends 'girls' to entrap politicians |date=20 March 2018 |work=The Times}} Cambridge Analytica said that the video footage was "edited and scripted to grossly misrepresent" the recorded conversations and company's business practices. Nix said that he had "entertained a series of ludicrous hypothetical scenarios", but insisted his company does not engage in entrapment or bribery.{{cite news |last1=Pham |first1=Sherisse |last2=Riley |first2=Charles |url=http://money.cnn.com/2018/03/20/technology/cambridge-analytica-channel-4-report/index.html |title=Cambridge Analytica responds after CEO filmed discussing bribery and entrapment |publisher=CNN |date=20 March 2018 |accessdate=22 March 2018}} In the third part of the series, Nix also said that Cambridge Analytica "ran all the digital campaign" for Trump. Nix stated they used communications that would be self-destructive, leaving no incriminating evidence. After the news segment was broadcast, the board of Cambridge Analytica suspended Nix as chief executive officer. The company also released a statement that the allegations did not represent the ethics of the company, and an independent entity would investigate Nix's statements.{{cite news |last=Lanxon |first=Nate |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-03-20/cambridge-analytica-used-disappearing-emails-in-campaign-report |title=Cambridge Analytica Boasted of Disappearing Emails in Campaigns |work=Bloomberg |date=20 March 2018 |accessdate=20 March 2018}} The investigation also raised questions regarding campaign finance law. During the 2016 election, the company was employed both by Trump's campaign and Robert Mercer's [[Make America Number 1]] Super [[Political Action Committee|PAC]] which supported Trump. While PACs are not limited in the amount of funds they can spend on behalf of a candidate, they are not allowed to coordinate strategy with the campaigns they are supporting. Nix's statements in the recorded video describe how the Trump campaign itself could "take the high road" and "stay clean", while the negative attacks were handled by the firm and the Super PAC, in a way which makes it "unattributable, untrackable". These statements potentially suggested unlawful coordination between Trump's campaign and the PAC, although Cambridge Analytica has denied this.{{cite news |last=Bump |first=Philip |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/politics/wp/2018/03/20/a-new-undercover-video-raises-significant-questions-about-cambridge-analyticas-elections-work/ |title=A new undercover video raises significant questions about Cambridge Analytica's elections work |work=The Washington Post |date=20 March 2018 |accessdate=20 March 2018}} ===Assessment of impact=== [[File:Cambridge Analytica protest Parliament Square4.jpg|thumb|Canadian whistleblower [[Christopher Wylie]] who was the former director of research at Cambridge Analytica]] Political scientists have been highly skeptical of claims made by Cambridge Analytica about the effectiveness of its microtargeting of voters (microtargeting refers to the process of "analyzing data to predict the behavior, interests, and opinions held by specific groups of people and then serving them the messages they're most likely to respond to").{{Cite news |url=https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2017/03/27/the-reclusive-hedge-fund-tycoon-behind-the-trump-presidency |title=The Reclusive Hedge-Fund Tycoon Behind the Trump Presidency |last=Mayer |first=Jane |date=17 March 2017 |work=The New Yorker|access-date=20 March 2018 |issn=0028-792X |df=dmy-all}}{{Cite news |url=https://www.theverge.com/2018/3/20/17138854/cambridge-analytica-facebook-data-trump-campaign-psychographic-microtargeting |title=Cambridge Analytica's Facebook data abuse shouldn't get credit for Trump |work=The Verge|access-date=20 March 2018 |df=dmy-all}} Political scientists note that access to digital data is not going to provide significantly more information than from public voter databases, and the digital data has limited value over time as the preferences of voters change. Political scientists also note that it is hard to infer political values from personality traits, which means that it is easy to mistarget the messages that are sent to voters with specific personality traits. Research discussed by [[Brendan Nyhan]] of Dartmouth College showed that it is extremely hard to alter voters' preferences because many likely voters are already committed partisans; as a result, it is easier to simply mobilize partisan voters.{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/13/upshot/fake-news-and-bots-may-be-worrisome-but-their-political-power-is-overblown.html |title=Fake News and Bots May Be Worrisome, but Their Political Power Is Overblown |last=Nyhan |first=Brendan |date=13 February 2018 |work=The New York Times|access-date=20 March 2018 |issn=0362-4331 |df=dmy-all}} Tufts University political scientist Eitan Hersh, who has published on microtargeting in campaigns, has expressed strong skepticism about Cambridge Analytica's methods and their purported effectiveness, saying "Every claim about psychographics etc made by or about [Cambridge Analytica] is BS."{{Cite news |url=https://reason.com/blog/2018/03/19/cambridge-analytica |title=Cambridge Analytica Was Doing Marketing, Not Black Magic |date=19 March 2018 |work=Reason|access-date=19 March 2018}} In 2017, CA claimed that it has psychological profiles of 220 million US citizens based on 5,000 separate data sets.{{cite news |url=https://fountainink.in/reportage/aadhaar-in-the-hand-of-spies- |title=Aadhaar in the hand of spies Big Data, global surveillance state and the identity project |author=Govind Krishnan V. |date=3 June 2017 |accessdate=27 August 2017 |publisher=Fountain Ink Magazine |df=dmy-all}} In March 2017, ''[[The New York Times]]'' reported that CA had exaggerated its capabilities: "Cambridge executives now concede that the company never used psychographics in the Trump campaign." Trump aides have also disputed CA's role in the campaign, describing it as "modest" and noting that none of the company's efforts involved psychographics. According to an aide and consultant for Ted Cruz's presidential campaign, their campaign stopped using CA after its psychographic models failed to identify likely Cruz supporters. The Cruz campaign ceased access to all of Cambridge's data after the [[South Carolina Republican primary, 2016|South Carolina Republican primary]] on 20 February 2016 when Cruz came in third after Trump and Rubio.{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/live/south-carolina-nevada-2016-election/ted-cruz-speaks-after-south-carolina-primary/ |title=Ted Cruz on South Carolina Primary |date=20 February 2016 |work=The New York Times|access-date=21 March 2018 |issn=0362-4331}} ===Privacy issues=== The use of [[personal data]] collected without knowledge or permission to establish sophisticated models of user's personalities raises ethical and [[Privacy concerns with social networking services|privacy issue]]s. CA operated out of the United States; its operations would be illegal in Europe with its stricter [[privacy law]]s. While Cruz was outspoken about protecting personal information from the government, his database of CA has been described as "political-voter [[surveillance]]". Regarding CA's use of Facebook users, a speaker for CA indicated that these users gave permission when signing up with the provider, while Facebook declared that "misleading people or misusing information" is in violation of Facebook's policies. In 2015, Facebook indicated that it was investigating the matter. In March 2018, Facebook announced that it had suspended the accounts of Strategic Communication Laboratories for failing to delete data on Facebook users that had been improperly collected.{{cite news |first=Elizabeth |last=Dwoskin |date=16 March 2018 |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-switch/wp/2018/03/16/facebook-bans-trump-campaigns-data-analytics-firm-for-taking-user-data/ |title=Facebook bans Trump campaign's data analytics firm for taking user data |work=[[The Washington Post]] |quote=Facebook said it was suspending the accounts of Strategic Communication Laboratories, the parent company of Cambridge Analytica, as well as the accounts of a University of Cambridge psychologist Aleksandr Kogan, and Christopher Wylie of Eunoia Technologies, Inc. Cambridge Analytica, a firm specializing in using online data to create voter personality profiles in order to target them with messages, ran data operations for Trump's presidential campaign. |df=dmy-all}} Alexander Nix suggested that data collection and microtargeting benefits the voters – because they receive messages about issues they care about. However, [[digital rights]] protection groups raised concerns that private information is collected, stored, and shared while individuals are "left in the dark about [it]" and have no control.{{cite web |url=http://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/2016-election-day/trump-campaign-pays-millions-overseas-big-data-firm-n677321 |first=Kate |last=Brannelly |title=Trump Campaign Pays Millions to Overseas Big Data Firm |publisher=[[NBC News]] |date=4 November 2016 |accessdate=5 November 2016 |df=dmy-all}} Significant backlash against Facebook came to light in March 2018, resulting in controversy as well as a $37 billion drop in the [[market capitalization]] of Facebook, as of 20 March.{{Cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/business-43462423 |title=Facebook's value falls $37bn amid backlash |date=19 March 2018 |publisher=BBC |access-date=20 March 2018 |df=dmy-all}} Due to the scandal of enabling monetization of Facebook personal data, one assessment was that only 41% of Facebook users trust the company.{{cite web |author1=Nelson Granados |title=Transparency: How Facebook Can Recover From The Cambridge Analytica Crisis |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/nelsongranados/2018/03/26/transparency-how-facebook-can-recover-from-the-cambridge-analytica-crisis/ |publisher=Forbes |accessdate=26 March 2018 |date=26 March 2018}} On 26 March, the US [[Federal Trade Commission]] announced it is "conducting an open investigation of Facebook Inc's privacy practices following the disclosure that 50 million users' data got into the hands of political consultancy Cambridge Analytica."{{cite news |title=U.S. FTC investigating Facebook's privacy practices |url=http://news.trust.org/item/20180326145505-6je9o/ |work=Reuters |date=26 March 2018 |quote=If the FTC finds Facebook violated terms of the consent decree, it has the power to fine the company thousands of dollars a day per violation, which could add up to billions of dollars. "The FTC takes very seriously recent press reports raising substantial concerns about the privacy practices of Facebook. Today, the FTC is confirming that it has an open non-public investigation into these practices," Tom Pahl, acting director of the FTC's Bureau of Consumer Protection, said in a statement.}} ==Elections== ===India=== In India, Cambridge Analytica had been used by the two largest political parties, [[BJP]] and [[Indian National Congress|Congress (INC)]] to carry out "in-depth electorate analysis" and influence voters, including in the [[Bihar Legislative Assembly election, 2010|2010 elections]] to the [[Bihar Legislative Assembly]].{{cite news |last1=Punit |first1=Itika |title=Cambridge Analytica’s parent firm proposed a massive political machine for India’s 2014 elections |url=https://qz.com/1239561/cambridge-analyticas-parent-firm-proposed-a-massive-political-machine-for-indias-2014-elections/ |accessdate=6 June 2018 |agency=Reuters |publisher=Quartz |date=28 March 2018}}{{cite web |title=Our Political data driven campaigns|publisher=Cambridge Analytica official website |accessdate=6 June 2018}}{{cite web |last=Punit |first=Itika Sharma |title=Why Cambridge Analytica was eager to play in the world's largest democracy |url=https://qz.com/1233040/cambridge-analytica-was-eager-to-play-in-the-worlds-largest-democracy/ |website=Quartz |accessdate=20 March 2018 |df=dmy-all}} 355 Indian Facebook users installed a Cambridge Analytica app, exposing the data of 562,455 users.{{cite web |last=Punit |first=Itika Sharma |title=Facebook admits Cambridge Analytica may have accessed the data of over 560,000 users in India – Quartz |url=https://qz.com/1245515/facebook-admits-cambridge-analytica-may-have-accessed-the-data-of-over-560000-users-in-india |website=Quartz |accessdate=5 April 2018 |date=5 April 2018}} In addition, [[Christopher Wylie]], the Cambridge Analytica [[whistleblower]], alleged that the company has offices and staff in India, and that the [[Indian National Congress]] party was a major client.{{cite news |title='Believe' Congress was a client, says Cambridge Analytica whistleblower |url=https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/politics-and-nation/believe-congress-was-a-client-says-cambridge-analytica-whistleblower/articleshow/63491061.cms |accessdate=23 April 2018 |publisher=[[The Economic Times]] |date=27 March 2018}} A [[BBC]] documentary clip showing a poster of the [[Indian National Congress]] in the office of former Cambridge Analytica expert [[Christopher Wylie]] went viral in India, sparking accusations that the company was manipulating both mainstream and social media in order to subvert Indian voters away from the [[Bharatiya Janata Party]] and towards the INC as part of a [[neocolonial]] effort to undermine Indian politics in favor of vested interests.{{cite web |title=BBC documentary clip goes viral, shows Congress poster in office of Cambridge Analytica's ex-CEO Alexander Nix |url=http://www.dnaindia.com/india/report-bbc-documentary-clip-goes-viral-shows-congress-poster-in-office-of-cambridge-analytica-s-ex-ceo-alexander-nix-2598837 |website=[[DNA India]] |accessdate=23 April 2018}} In early 2018 Cambridge Analytica made a 50-page proposal for the INC for both the upcoming [[Indian general election, 2019|2019 general election in India]] and their upcoming electoral campaign for the Indian states of [[Karnataka]], Chhattisgarh and [[Madhya Pradesh]] state elections in 2018.{{cite web |title=Cambridge Analytica made 2019 roadmap for Congress; party denies any deal |url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/lucknow/cambridge-analytica-made-2019-roadmap-for-congress-party-denies-any-deal/articleshow/63823483.cms |website=[[The Times of India]] |accessdate=23 April 2018}} ===Kenya=== CA ran campaigns in secret during Kenya's [[Kenyan general election, 2013|2013]] and [[Kenyan general election, 2017|2017 elections]].{{cite web |last1=Dahir |first1=Abdi Latif |title="We'd stage the whole thing": Cambridge Analytica filmed boasting of its role in Kenya's polls |url=https://qz.com/1233084/channel-4-news-films-cambridge-analytica-execs-saying-they-staged-kenya-uhuru-kenyatta-elections/ |website=Quartz |accessdate=20 March 2018 |df=dmy-all}} In 2018, a CA employee said that his predecessor at the company had been found dead in his hotel room in Kenya while working on [[Uhuru Kenyatta]]'s 2013 campaign.{{cite news |last1=Lang'at |first1=Patrick |title=Exposed: Analytica staff died in Kenya |url=https://www.nation.co.ke/news/politics/Cambridge-Analytica-staff-Dan-Mure-an-died-in-Kenya/1064-4351058-11gicwcz/index.html |accessdate=21 March 2018 |work=Daily Nation |date=21 March 2018 |language=en-UK}} The company claimed on its website to have conducted a survey of 47,000 Kenyans during the 2013 elections in order to understand "key national and local political issues, levels of trust in key politicians, voting behaviours/intentions, and preferred information channels". According to verified sources, CA worked with 360 Media a company formed by [[Simon Gicharu]] founder of [[Mount Kenya University]] and Tom Mshindi Editor in Chief of [[Nation Media Group]]. Gicharu's 360 developing online campaigns in the 2017 Kenyan elections portraying "Raila Odinga as a blood-thirsty individual who is also sympathetic to Al-Shabaab and having no development agenda," whilst portraying the incumbent President Kenyatta as "tough on terrorism, and being good for the economy."{{cite news |last1=Matende |first1=David |title=Media, like false preachers |url=http://nairobilawmonthly.com/index.php/2018/06/05/media-like-false-preachers |accessdate=6 August 2018 |work=Nairobi Law Monthly |date=2018-06-05}} After the revelations in March 2018, where CA staff boasted of their power in Kenya, opposition figures called for an investigation. Norman Magaya, an official of the [[National Super Alliance]], accused CA and the ruling [[Jubilee Party]] of committing a crime and called for an investigation.{{cite web |title=Cambridge Analytica's Kenyan role queried |website=BBC News |date=20 March 2018 |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-43471707 | access-date=23 March 2018}} The ruling Jubilee Party downplayed CA's role, saying it had hired the firm's parent company, to assist with branding.{{cite news |title=Cambridge Analytica's Kenyan role queried |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-43471707 |accessdate=21 March 2018 |publisher=BBC |date=20 March 2018}} ===Malta=== In its Disinformation and 'fake news' inquiry, published on 29 July 2018, the UK Parliament's Digital, Culture, Media and Sport Committee noted that it is believed that CA, or its associated companies, worked with the Labour Party in [[Malta]], on the 2013 general election campaign.{{cite web |last1=Digital, Culture, Media and Sport Committee |title=Disinformation and 'fake news': Interim Report |url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm201719/cmselect/cmcumeds/363/36309.htm#_idTextAnchor053}} Several sources claim, including assassinated journalist [[Daphne Caruana Galizia]], that CA had close relationships with [[Henley & Partners]] who would immediately after the election introduce and run a lucrative Citizenship by Investment Program in Malta.{{cite news|url=https://www.imidaily.com/editors-picks/hpsclcambridge2/ |title= Henley & Partners Speaks Out on SCL, Cambridge Analytica, House of Commons Report |date=2018-08-07 |accessdate=2018-11-07}} {{cite news |work=Caribbean News Now! |title=UK parliamentary report calls for criminal investigation of Henley and SCL |url=https://wp.caribbeannewsnow.com/2018/07/30/uk-parliamentary-report-calls-for-criminal-investigation-of-henley-and-scl/}}{{cite news |last1=Chenoweth |first1=Neil |title=Who ordered the assassination of Maltese journalist Daphne Caruana Galizia? |url=https://www.afr.com/news/politics/world/who-ordered-the-assassination-of-maltese-journalist-daphne-caruana-galizia-20180426-h0zbak |publisher=Australian Financial Review}} The Maltese Government issued a press release denying the claims and calling the report and its sources "fake news".{{cite web |last1=Department of Information |title=STATEMENT BY THE GOVERNMENT OF MALTA: Government of Malta makes official representations regarding UK DCMS Committee report |url=https://www.gov.mt/en/Government/Press%20Releases/Pages/2018/July/30/PR181687.aspx}} [[Henley & Partners]] denied any wrongdoing. According to Henley & Partners, there was never a formal working relationship with CA.{{cite news|url=https://www.maltatoday.com.mt/news/world/85644/passportsellers_henley_and_cambridge_analyticas_nix_exchanged_ideas_on_caribbean_election#.W-QmuieNzUI |title= Passport-sellers Henley and Cambridge Analytica’s Nix ‘exchanged ideas’ on Caribbean election |date=2018-03-28 |accessdate=2018-11-07}} ===Mexico=== After the Facebook scandal involving Cambridge Analytica, ''[[Forbes]]'' published that the British news program [[Channel 4 News]] had mentioned the existence of proof revealing ties between the [[Institutional Revolutionary Party|PRI]] and Cambridge Analytica, suggesting a ''[[modus operandi]]'' similar to the one in the United States. According to [[Channel 4 News]]' Guillermo Galdos, CA worked for the PRI at least until January 2018.{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com.mx/cambridge-analytica-mexico-pri-enero-2018-channel-4-news/|title=Cambridge Analytica trabajó con el PRI: Channel 4 News|website=Forbes México|date=30 March 2018}}{{cite web|url=http://www.elfinanciero.com.mx/opinion/javier-murillo/cambridge-analytica-sigan-la-ruta-del-dinero|title=Cambridge Analytica, sigan la ruta del dinero|first=Javier|last=Murillo|website=El Financiero}}{{cite web|url=https://elpais.com/elpais/2018/03/22/inenglish/1521710735_571195.html|title=The distorted online networks of Mexico's election campaign|first1=Fernando|last1=Peinado|first2=Elvira|last2=Palomo|first3=Javier|last3=Galán|date=22 March 2018|newspaper=El País}} An investigation was requested.{{cite web|url=https://www.proceso.com.mx/528182/exigen-al-inai-investigar-a-cambridge-analytica-facebook-y-desarrolladoras-de-apps-en-mexico|title=Exigen al INAI investigar a Cambridge Analytica, Facebook y desarrolladoras de Apps en México|website=Proceso|date=2 April 2018}} In 2017 the company had reached out to [[Institutional Revolutionary Party|PRI]], Mexico's ruling political party, in order to bolster the party's presidential campaign during the largest-ever political elections of 2018. The party decided that it was sufficiently equipped to mess with the election on its own, but still paid Cambridge Analytica to prevent it from working with rival parties.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/06/24/world/americas/mexico-election-cambridge-analytica.html|title=Mexico's Hardball Politics Get Even Harder as PRI Fights to Hold On to Power|access-date=2018-07-01|language=en}} ===United Kingdom=== [[File:Cambridge Analytica protest Parliament Square1.jpg|thumb|A protest following the Cambridge Analytica scandal, 29 March 2018]] Many donors to the UK Conservative Party reportedly have connections to the parent company of Cambridge Analytica.[https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/mar/21/tory-donors-among-investors-in-cambridge-analytica-parent-firm-scl-group Tory donors among investors in Cambridge Analytica parent firm] ''[[The Guardian]]'' CA became involved in the 2016 [[Brexit referendum]] supporting "persuadable" voters to vote for leaving the [[European Union]].{{cite web |url=http://www.thetimes.co.uk/edition/world/trump-calls-in-brexit-experts-to-target-voters-pf0hwcts9 |first=Rhys |last=Blakely |title=Data scientists target 20 million new voters for Trump |work=[[The Times]] |date=22 September 2016 |accessdate=4 October 2016 |df=dmy-all}} Articles by [[Carole Cadwalladr]] in ''[[The Observer]]'' and ''[[The Guardian|Guardian]]'' newspapers, respectively published in February and May 2017, speculated in detail that CA had influenced both the [[Brexit]]/Vote Leave option in the [[United Kingdom European Union membership referendum, 2016|UK's 2016 EU membership referendum]] and [[Donald Trump presidential campaign, 2016|Trump's 2016 US presidential campaign]] with Robert Mercer's backing of [[Donald Trump]] being key. They also discuss the legality of using the social data farmed.{{cite news |last=Barnett |first=Anthony |url=http://www.nybooks.com/daily/2017/12/14/democracy-and-the-machinations-of-mind-control/ |title=Democracy and the Machinations of Mind Control |work=New York Review of Books |date=14 December 2017 |accessdate=16 December 2017 |df=dmy-all}}{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2017/feb/26/robert-mercer-breitbart-war-on-media-steve-bannon-donald-trump-nigel-farage |first=Carole |last=Cadwalladr |title=Robert Mercer: the big data billionaire waging war on mainstream media |work=[[The Observer]] |date=26 February 2017 |accessdate=27 February 2017 |df=dmy-all}}{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2017/may/07/the-great-british-brexit-robbery-hijacked-democracy |first=Carole |last=Cadwalladr |title=The Great British Brexit robbery how our democracy was hijacked |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=7 May 2017 |accessdate=7 May 2017 |df=dmy-all}} CA is pursuing legal action over the claims made in Cadwalladr's articles. No campaign contributions, in cash or in kind, by Cambridge Analytica were reported to the UK electoral authorities. Both CA and Leave.eu refused to comment on any donation of services.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2017/feb/26/us-billionaire-mercer-helped-back-brexit |title=Revealed: how US billionaire helped to back Brexit |first=Carole |last=Cadwalladr |date=26 February 2017 |newspaper=[[The Guardian]]}} On 23 March 2018, it was reported that a former employee, Brittany Kaiser, who was the company's former director of business development, has revealed that the company misled the public and MPs over its links with [[Leave.EU]] and the analysis of data which had been provided by [[UK Independence Party|UKIP]]. She said she felt she had lied by supporting Cambridge Analytica's company line that it had done "no paid or unpaid work" for Leave.EU. "In my opinion, I was lying. In my opinion I felt like we should say, 'this is exactly what we did'".{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/news/2018/mar/23/cambridge-analytica-misled-mps-over-work-for-leave-eu-says-ex-director-brittany-kaiser |title=Cambridge Analytica misled MPs over work for Leave.EU, says ex-director |work=[[The Guardian]] |author=Paul Lewis and Paul Hilder |date=23 March 2018 |accessdate=24 March 2018}} The following day, it was reported that the company claimed that it would be able to affect the outcome of the Referendum and that it had produced a 10-page document headed "Big Data Solutions for the EU Referendum", claiming it could single out 'Brexiteers' among voters, donors, politicians and journalists.{{cite web |url=https://www.standard.co.uk/news/uk/cambridge-analytica-bragged-we-have-vast-data-for-brexit-vote-a3797441.html |title=Cambridge Analytica bragged: We have vast data for Brexit vote |work=[[London Evening Standard]] |author=Joe Murphy, Political Editor |date=24 March 2018 |accessdate=24 March 2018}} DW reported in March 2018 that "Whistleblower [[Christopher Wylie]] told UK lawmakers during a committee hearing on Tuesday that a firm linked to Cambridge Analytica helped the official [[Vote Leave]] campaign [the official pro-Brexit group headed by [[Boris Johnson]] and Michael Gove] circumvent campaign financing laws during the Brexit referendum.""[http://www.dw.com/en/what-role-did-cambridge-analytica-play-in-the-brexit-vote/a-43151460 What role did Cambridge Analytica play in the Brexit vote?]". ''Deutsche Welle.'' 27 March 2018. ===United States=== Laurence Levy, a lawyer with the law firm [[Bracewell & Giuliani]], advises [[Rebekah Mercer]], [[Steve Bannon]], and [[Alexander Nix]] on the legality of their company, Cambridge Analytica, being involved in [[U.S. elections]]. He advises that Nix and any foreign nationals without a [[Permanent residence (United States)|green card]] working for the company must not be involved in any decision making regarding any work the company performs for any clients related to [[U.S. elections]]. He further advises Nix to recuse himself from any involvement with the company's [[U.S. election]] work because he is not a [[U.S. citizen]].{{cite web |title=Participation in US Elections |url=http://msnbcmedia.msn.com/i/TODAY/z_Creative/LEVY_MEMO_DM_4636592_v1_Memo_re__Participation_in_US_Elections.pdf |date=22 July 2014|access-date=23 March 2018 |last=Levy |first=Laurence |via=[[MSNBC]] |publisher=[[Bracewell & Giuliani|Bracewell & Giuliani LLP]]}}{{Cite news |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/elections/wylie-foreigners-worked-cambridge-analytica-nc-senate-campaign-n859526 |title=Wylie: Foreigners worked for Cambridge Analytica on NC Senate campaign |work=NBC News|access-date=23 March 2018 |language=en-US}} ====2014 midterm elections==== CA had entered the US market in 2012 (or 2013), and was involved in 44 [[United States Congress|US congressional]], [[United States Senate|US Senate]] and state-level elections in the 2014 midterm elections.{{Cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/cruz-campaign-paid-750000-to-psychographic-profiling-company/2015/10/19/6c83e508-743f-11e5-9cbb-790369643cf9_story.html |title=Cruz campaign paid $750,000 to 'psychographic profiling' company |last=Sellers |first=Frances Stead |authorlink=Frances Stead Sellers |date=19 October 2015 |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |issn=0190-8286| access-date = 26 February 2016 |df=dmy-all}} The company worked with the [[John R. Bolton#John Bolton Super PAC|John Bolton Super PAC]] on a major digital and TV campaign focused on senate races in Arkansas, North Carolina and New Hampshire and helped turn out voters for the Republican candidates in those states. Two of the Republican candidates backed by the Bolton Super PAC, [[Thom Tillis]] in [[United States Senate election in North Carolina, 2014|North Carolina]] and [[Tom Cotton]] in [[United States Senate election in Arkansas, 2014|Arkansas]], won their Senate bids, while [[Scott Brown (politician)|Scott Brown]] lost in [[United States Senate election in New Hampshire, 2014|New Hampshire]]. The PAC ran 15 different spots each in North Carolina and Arkansas and 17 in New Hampshire, mostly online with some targeted directly to households using Dish and [[DirecTV]]. All were intended to push Bolton's national security agenda.{{cite web |url=http://adage.com/article/campaign-trail/hyped-data-firm-s-promise-tested-iowa/302412 |title=Much-Hyped Data Firm's Promise Could Be Tested in Iowa |work=Advertising Age| access-date = 26 February 2016 |df=dmy-all}} CA also supported [[Thom Tillis]]'s successful campaign to oust [[Kay Hagan]] as a senator for North Carolina. The firm was credited for its role in identifying a sizeable cluster of North Carolinians who prioritised foreign affairs, which encouraged Tillis to shift the conversation from state-level debates over education policy to charges that incumbent Kay Hagan had failed to take [[ISIS]]'s rise seriously.{{cite web |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/politics/features/2015-11-12/is-the-republican-party-s-killer-data-app-for-real |title=Cruz-Connected Data Miner Aims to Get Inside U.S. Voters' Heads |website=Bloomberg.com | access-date = 26 February 2016}} Tillis's campaign and the North Carolina Republican Party paid Cambridge Analytica $345,000 for these services.{{cite news |last1=Murphy |first1=Brian |last2=Bonner |first2=Lynn |url=http://www.newsobserver.com/news/politics-government/politics-columns-blogs/under-the-dome/article205946479.html |title=Tillis and NC Republicans paid $345,000 to the data firm that's now banned from Facebook |work=The News & Observer |date=19 March 2018 |accessdate=20 March 2018 |df=dmy-all}} CA sent dozens of non-U.S. citizens to provide campaign strategy and messaging advice to Republican candidates in 2014, opening the firm and individuals to prosecution under the [[Foreign Agents Registration Act]], for being foreign agents having not registered through the [[United States Department of Justice]] as such.{{Cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/former-cambridge-analytica-workers-say-firm-sent-foreigners-to-advise-us-campaigns/2018/03/25/6a0d7d90-2fa2-11e8-911f-ca7f68bff0fc_story.html |title=Former Cambridge Analytica workers say firm sent foreigners to advise U.S. campaigns |last=Timberg |first=Craig |date=25 March 2018 |work=Washington Post|access-date=26 March 2018 |last2=Hamburger |first2=Tom |language=en-US |issn=0190-8286}} ====2016 presidential election==== CA's involvement in the [[Republican Party presidential primaries, 2016|2016 Republican Party presidential primaries]] became known in July 2015. As of December 2015, CA claimed to have collected up to 5,000 data points on over 220 million Americans.{{cite web |url=https://cambridgeanalytica.org/about |title=About Us |publisher=Cambridge Analytica |accessdate=27 December 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160216023554/https://cambridgeanalytica.org/about |archivedate=16 February 2016 |df=dmy-all}} At that time [[Robert Mercer (businessman)|Robert Mercer]] was a major supporter of [[Ted Cruz]].{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/04/11/us/politics/hedge-fund-magnaterobert-mercer-emerges-as-a-generous-backer-of-ted-cruz.html |last1=Lichtblau |first1=E |last2=Stevenson |first2=A |title=Hedge-Fund Magnate Robert Mercer Emerges as a Generous Backer of Cruz |work=The New York Times |date=10 April 2015 |accessdate=6 February 2016 |df=dmy-all}} The Mercer family funded CA directly and indirectly through several [[super-PACs]] as well as through payments via Cruz's campaign. Ted Cruz became an early major client of CA in the 2016 presidential campaign. Just prior to the [[Iowa Republican caucuses, 2016|Iowa caucuses]], the Cruz campaign had spent $3 million for CA's services,{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/feb/01/ted-cruz-trump-iowa-caucus-voter-targeting |author=Harry Davies |title=Ted Cruz erased Trump's Iowa lead by spending millions on voter targeting |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=1 February 2016 |accessdate=7 February 2016 |df=dmy-all}} with additional money coming from allied Super-PACs. After Cruz's win at the Iowa caucus CA was credited with having been able to identify and motivate potential voters.{{cite news |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/politics/articles/2016-02-02/how-ted-cruz-engineered-his-iowa-triumph |author=Sasha Issenberg |title=How Ted Cruz Engineered His Iowa Triumph |work=Bloomberg.com |date=2 February 2016 |accessdate=8 February 2016 |df=dmy-all}}{{cite news |url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/cambridge-analytica-congratulates-senator-ted-cruz-on-iowa-caucus-win-300213608.html |title=Cambridge Analytica Congratulates Senator Ted Cruz on Iowa Caucus Win |agency=[[PR Newswire]] |date=2 February 2016 |accessdate=8 February 2016 |df=dmy-all}} Ultimately the Cruz campaign spent $5.8 million on work by CA. [[Ben Carson]] was a second client of CA; [[Ben Carson presidential campaign, 2016|his campaign]] had paid $220,000 for "data management" and "web service" as reported in October 2015.{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/cruz-campaign-paid-750000-to-psychographic-profiling-company/2015/10/19/6c83e508-743f-11e5-9cbb-790369643cf9_story.html |first=Frances Stead |last=Sellers |title=Cruz campaign paid $750,000 to 'psychographic profiling' company |work=[[The Washington Post]] |date=19 October 2015 |accessdate=7 February 2016 |df=dmy-all}} [[Marco Rubio presidential campaign|Marco Rubio's campaign]] was supported by Optimus Consulting.{{cite web |url=http://www.campaignsandelections.com/campaign-insider/2646/organization-and-analytics-help-take-down-trump-in-iowa |first1=Sean J. |last=Miller |title=Organization and Analytics Help Take Down Trump in Iowa |work=CampaignsandElections.com |date=2 February 2016 |publisher= |accessdate=23 February 2016 |df=dmy-all}} Meanwhile, the third competitor, Governor [[John Kasich]], was supported by rivalling firm Applecart.{{cite web |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/politics/articles/2015-11-24/a-new-data-mining-technique-to-uncover-new-hampshire-influencers |title=Data-Mining Firm Searches for Voters by Combing High School Yearbooks |work=Bloomberg.com |df=dmy-all}} After Cruz dropped out of the race for the Republican presidential nomination in May 2016, Robert Mercer and his daughter [[Rebekah Mercer (donor)|Rebekah Mercer]] started to support Trump.{{cite web |url=http://www.nationalreview.com/article/438739/trump-campaigns-data-firm-partner-cambridge-analytica-worked-cruz |first=Eliana |last=Johnson |title=The GOP nominee makes a late attempt at data-driven targeted messaging |work=[[National Review]] |date=5 August 2016 |accessdate=4 October 2016 |df=dmy-all}} In August, it became known that CA followed their allegiance and worked for Trump's presidential campaign.
